learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the major phases of historical European staging traditions and conventions and how they operate textually and performatively.
Recognise how shifting historical movements, especially in relation to science, sex, and the supernatural, interact with and are figured in dramatic and theatrical conventions and developments.
Comprehend the importance of political and social contexts, genre expectations, and specific spaces on audience reception of historical European theatre.
Understand the critical context (both then and now) for historical European theatre.
Recontextualise historical European theatre for a present-day audience through group performance.

assessments.due_date:
Week 2 - Week 12

NOTE: Participation is not assessed in week 11 due to the public holiday.
assessments.task_description:
A mark out of twenty will be awarded to you based on your participation during in-class discussions and tutorial activities throughout the semester. You are graded on participation in classes for this course; attendance itself is not sufficient to constitute 'participation'. Participation means willing involvement, active engagement with the text, the critical reading and the tasks at hand, asking questions, working well in groups, and demonstrating evidence of having listened to the lecture. Acting ability is not assessed. It is your responsibility to ensure that your attendance has been recorded. Central to group work is accountability, and the relationships that you develop with your peers. Peer accountability will be considered when determining the group work aspect of your participation grade when preparing for your group performance.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
In this Research Essay, you will demonstrate your acquired knowledge and research skills by writing about a contemporary realisation of one of the plays studied in this course. 

This task will assess your ability to:

  • answer (or produce) a relevant and compelling research question;
  • provide an analytic approach to the topic and its relevant issues;
  • construct a strong argument; and
  • provide evidence from one required text and secondary material to support this argument.

The referencing style used for Drama assignments is MLA, 9th edition.

A detailed assignment brief will be made available via Blackboard in due course.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit on Turnitin via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
14/10/2024 - 18/10/2024

Performances will take place in regular tutorial hours.
assessments.task_description:
Working in groups, this task will invite you to produce a performance response to the three major themes of the course; that is, the relationship between science, sex and the supernatural, and how these are interrogated through the spatial conventions of the historical European theatrical tradition. Drawing on the texts that we have studied in the course, you will produce a performance of approximately ten minutes' duration. This performance may be staged in a non-traditional venue. This task invites you to respond to the course in an embodied way, while maintaining the critical and analytical rigour of your interrogation.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment

  • All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)
  • Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.
  • Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of:
  • Moderation of marking;
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction

This lecture will introduce the structure of the course, and think about how staging superstition and anxiety around sex and gender roles shaped Early Modern theatrical culture..


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction This lecture will introduce the structure of the course, and think about how staging superstition and anxiety around sex and gender roles shaped Early Modern theatrical culture..

learning_activities.topic: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: NO TUTORIALS

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Outdoor Bodies (1)

In this lecture, we use "Richard III" to think through how 'othered' bodies were represented on the outdoor stage.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Outdoor Bodies (1) In this lecture, we use "Richard III" to think through how 'othered' bodies were represented on the outdoor stage.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Disability

In this tutorial, we consider interactions between the human body and the outdoor playing space, with reference to Richard III.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Disability In this tutorial, we consider interactions between the human body and the outdoor playing space, with reference to Richard III.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Outdoor Bodies (2)

This lecture will use "Othello" to introduce various elements of Early Modern performance practice, especially as they relate to sex and gender.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Outdoor Bodies (2) This lecture will use "Othello" to introduce various elements of Early Modern performance practice, especially as they relate to sex and gender.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Early Modern Bodies

This tutorial will focus on staging (and interrogating) the various kinds of bodies required in Early Modern performance, particularly in relation to gendered bodies.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Early Modern Bodies This tutorial will focus on staging (and interrogating) the various kinds of bodies required in Early Modern performance, particularly in relation to gendered bodies.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Indoor Magic

This lecture uses Shakespeare's late play "The Tempest" to illustrate the metaphorical role that magic and conjuring perform across the Early Modern period.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Indoor Magic This lecture uses Shakespeare's late play "The Tempest" to illustrate the metaphorical role that magic and conjuring perform across the Early Modern period.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Fairies

In this tutorial, we will investigate the figure of the fairy on the Early Modern and historical European stage through the figures of Prospero, Caliban and Ariel in "The Tempest".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Fairies In this tutorial, we will investigate the figure of the fairy on the Early Modern and historical European stage through the figures of Prospero, Caliban and Ariel in "The Tempest".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Staging the City

In this lecture, we position "The Alchemist" as part magic show and part City comedy to consider a more satirical position on magic in the indoor theatre.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Staging the City In this lecture, we position "The Alchemist" as part magic show and part City comedy to consider a more satirical position on magic in the indoor theatre.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Magicians

In this tutorial, we look at the superstition surrounding maigicians in the Early Modern era, and the specific anxieties they represent.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Magicians In this tutorial, we look at the superstition surrounding maigicians in the Early Modern era, and the specific anxieties they represent.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Outdoor Illusions

This lecture introduces our exploration of early attempts at meta-theatre, using the case study of Calderon de la Barca's "Life is a Dream" and its mixing of illusions and dreams.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Outdoor Illusions This lecture introduces our exploration of early attempts at meta-theatre, using the case study of Calderon de la Barca's "Life is a Dream" and its mixing of illusions and dreams.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Heroes

This tutorial will focus on the figure of the hero in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to Segismundo from Calderon's "Life is a Dream".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Heroes This tutorial will focus on the figure of the hero in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to Segismundo from Calderon's "Life is a Dream".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Indoor Illusions

This week's lecture introduces the figure of the sexual outlaw through Moliere's "Don Juan" in this iteration, in the form of a sexually voracious man and his supernatural comeuppance.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Indoor Illusions This week's lecture introduces the figure of the sexual outlaw through Moliere's "Don Juan" in this iteration, in the form of a sexually voracious man and his supernatural comeuppance.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Outlaws

This tutorial will focus on agents of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to the sexual outlaw in "Don Juan".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Outlaws This tutorial will focus on agents of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, with specific reference to the sexual outlaw in "Don Juan".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Enter the Actress (1)

This week's lecture turns its attention a play that interrogates the gendered and sexualised expectations of the outlaw-figure, in Aphra Behn's "The Rover".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Enter the Actress (1) This week's lecture turns its attention a play that interrogates the gendered and sexualised expectations of the outlaw-figure, in Aphra Behn's "The Rover".

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Women

In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Behn's "The Rover". Group allocations will also be finalised for the Group Performance Project.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Women In this tutorial, we consider women and the feminine allure as an agent of chaos in the historical European theatrical tradition, through the case study of Behn's "The Rover". Group allocations will also be finalised for the Group Performance Project.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Enter the Actress (2)

This lecture considers the male playwright's response to the arrival of women on- and off-stage, through the case study of William Congreve's "Love for Love" which helpfully also includes a mad, superstitious figure coded as male.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Enter the Actress (2) This lecture considers the male playwright's response to the arrival of women on- and off-stage, through the case study of William Congreve's "Love for Love" which helpfully also includes a mad, superstitious figure coded as male.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Rehearsals

This tutorial will introduce the Group Performance Project task, and assign groups so out-of-class rehearsals can be scheduled across the following fortnight.

Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Rehearsals This tutorial will introduce the Group Performance Project task, and assign groups so out-of-class rehearsals can be scheduled across the following fortnight.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Triumph of Reason (1)

In this week's lecture, we begin our conclusion of this period of theatre history by considering a play that depicts the triumph of reason, Marivaux's "The Dispute".

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Triumph of Reason (1) In this week's lecture, we begin our conclusion of this period of theatre history by considering a play that depicts the triumph of reason, Marivaux's "The Dispute".

This tutorial will be used for rehearsals for the upcoming Group Performance Project.

Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Rehearsals This tutorial will be used for rehearsals for the upcoming Group Performance Project.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Triumph of Reason (2)

In this final lecture, we look at a play that moves from the excess Sturm und Drang movement into the reason and order of Romanticism, Schiller's "Mary Stuart".

Please note this lecture will be pre-recorded due to falling on a public holiday.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Triumph of Reason (2) In this final lecture, we look at a play that moves from the excess Sturm und Drang movement into the reason and order of Romanticism, Schiller's "Mary Stuart". Please note this lecture will be pre-recorded due to falling on a public holiday.

As the regular tutorial time falls on a public holiday, students will instead book supervised rehearsal time with the drama technician for their upcoming group performance project on an alternate date in Week 11. Bookable dates and times will be communicated during semester via Blackboard.
